interpretation_philosophy: We present facts from reliable sources (primarily Wikipedia) with transparent source attribution. For controversial topics, we acknowledge the controversy and present the mainstream scientific/historical consensus while noting that interpretations may vary.

facts.statement: World War I lasted from 1914 to 1918

source.summary: WWI was a global conflict from July 28, 1914 to November 11, 1918

facts.interpretation_note: Dates are historically documented and undisputed.

facts.statement: World War II lasted from 1939 to 1945

source.summary: WWII was a global conflict from September 1, 1939 to September 2, 1945

facts.interpretation_note: Dates are historically documented and undisputed.

facts.statement: COVID-19 pandemic began in late 2019

source.summary: First cases identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019

facts.interpretation_note: The origin date and location are documented. Origins and response remain subjects of ongoing investigation and debate.

facts.statement: Biological sex in humans is primarily determined by sex chromosomes

value.intersex_note: Intersex variations exist (estimates ~0.018-1.7% depending on definition)

source.summary: Human sex chromosomes are X and Y; typical patterns are XX (female) and XY (male)

facts.interpretation_note: This describes biological sex based on chromosomes. Gender identity is a separate concept related to psychological and social identity. Intersex variations exist. This is a complex topic with biological, social, and personal dimensions.

facts.statement: Normal human body temperature is approximately 37°C (98.6°F)

value.note: Varies by individual, time of day, and measurement method

source.summary: Average oral temperature is about 36.8°C (98.2°F); traditional 37°C is slightly high

facts.interpretation_note: Well-established medical fact, though exact values vary slightly.

facts.statement: Speed of light in vacuum is approximately 299,792 km/s

source.summary: The speed of light in vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 m/s by definition

facts.interpretation_note: Fundamental physical constant, precisely defined and measured.

facts.statement: Acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s²

value.note: Varies slightly by location (9.76 to 9.83 m/s²)

source.summary: Standard gravity is defined as 9.80665 m/s²

facts.interpretation_note: Well-established physical measurement.

facts.statement: Water boils at 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure

value.note: Boiling point varies with altitude and pressure

source.summary: Water boils at 100°C at sea level pressure

facts.interpretation_note: Basic chemistry fact, well-established.

facts.statement: There are 8 planets in the Solar System (since 2006)

value.note: Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006

source.summary: IAU definition from 2006 recognizes 8 planets

facts.interpretation_note: Official IAU classification. Some still consider Pluto a planet colloquially.

facts.statement: There are 7 continents (most common model)

value.note: Some models use 6 continents (combining Europe and Asia into Eurasia, or Americas)

source.summary: Seven-continent model is most commonly taught in English-speaking countries

facts.interpretation_note: Different models exist (5, 6, or 7 continents), but 7-continent model is most common.

facts.statement: Warsaw is the capital of Poland

source.summary: Warsaw is the capital and largest city of Poland

facts.interpretation_note: Undisputed fact.

facts.statement: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters

source.summary: Mount Everest is Earth's highest mountain above sea level (8,849 m)

facts.interpretation_note: Height was remeasured in 2020 and agreed upon by Nepal and China.

facts.statement: There are 5 oceans on Earth

value.note: Southern Ocean was officially recognized in 2000

source.summary: Five ocean divisions: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Arctic, and Southern

facts.interpretation_note: Traditionally 4 oceans, but Southern Ocean officially recognized since 2000.

facts.statement: The modern Internet began with ARPANET in 1969, World Wide Web in 1991

value.www_note: Tim Berners-Lee released WWW to public in 1991

source.summary: ARPANET was the first packet-switching network (1969); WWW made internet accessible (1991)

facts.interpretation_note: Internet history is complex, but these are key milestone dates.

facts.statement: 5G technology does NOT cause COVID-19 or spread viruses

value.reality: Viruses cannot travel on radio waves. 5G uses non-ionizing radiation.
value.scientific_consensus: No causal link between 5G and COVID-19

source.summary: Scientific consensus: 5G does not cause or spread COVID-19. Viruses cannot travel on radio waves.

facts.interpretation_note: This is a debunked conspiracy theory. Scientific evidence is clear.

facts.statement: ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose electronic computers, was completed in 1945

value.name: ENIAC
value.note: First programmable, electronic, general-purpose digital computer

source.summary: ENIAC was completed in 1945 and was among the first general-purpose electronic computers

facts.interpretation_note: Computer history has many milestones; ENIAC is one of the most significant early computers.

facts.statement: The European Union was formally established by the Maastricht Treaty in 1993

value.note: EU evolved from earlier European Communities (EEC, 1957)

source.summary: EU was established by the Maastricht Treaty which came into force on 1 November 1993

facts.interpretation_note: EU has complex history with precursor organizations, but 1993 is the official founding date.

facts.statement: The United Nations was founded in 1945 after World War II

source.summary: UN was established on October 24, 1945, after WWII with 51 founding members

facts.interpretation_note: Widely documented historical fact.

facts.statement: United States declared independence on July 4, 1776

source.summary: Declaration of Independence was adopted on July 4, 1776

facts.interpretation_note: Well-documented historical event.

facts.statement: Poland regained independence on November 11, 1918 after 123 years of partitions

source.summary: Poland's Independence Day is celebrated on 11 November, marking the restoration of a sovereign Polish state in 1918

facts.interpretation_note: Independence was a process throughout 1918; 11 November is the commonly recognized symbolic date.

facts.statement: Poland joined NATO on March 12, 1999

source.summary: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic joined NATO on 12 March 1999

facts.interpretation_note: Widely accepted accession date for Poland's entry into NATO.

facts.statement: Poland joined the European Union on May 1, 2004

source.summary: On 1 May 2004, Poland and 9 other countries acceded to the European Union

facts.interpretation_note: Poland formally acceded to the EU on 1 May 2004.

facts.statement: The Solidarity (Solidarność) trade union movement emerged in Poland in 1980 at the Gdańsk Shipyard

source.summary: Solidarity was founded in September 1980 at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdańsk, Poland

facts.interpretation_note: Key movement in Poland's opposition to communist rule; 1980 is the commonly cited founding year.

facts.statement: The Polish Round Table Talks in 1989 led to semi-free elections and the beginning of the end of communist rule in Poland

source.summary: The Polish Round Table Agreement of 1989 led to semi-free elections on 4 June 1989 and a peaceful transition away from communist rule

facts.interpretation_note: The Round Table Talks and 4 June 1989 elections are widely seen as the start of the end of communist rule in Poland.
